snippet: Byron D. Trott, an adviser to Warren Buffett and a former Goldman Sachs vice chairman, detailed how Mr. Buffett's investment in Goldman materialized.
abstract: Byron D. Trott, an adviser to Warren Buffett and a former Goldman Sachs vice chairman, detailed how Mr. Buffett's investment in Goldman materialized.

headline.main: Buffett's Goldman Deal Is Topic in an Insider Case
headline.print_headline: Buffett’s Goldman Deal Is Topic in an Insider Case

snippet: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. Wednesday's selection includes I.B.M. banning Apple's Siri because it doesn't trust her, a missing iPhone posting photo clues on the Web and...
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. Wednesday's selection includes I.B.M. banning Apple's Siri because it doesn't trust her, a missing iPhone posting photo clues on the Web and a venture capitalist saying there is little sexism in his industry.

headline.main: Today's Scuttlebot: Cyberspy School and Internet Destruction

snippet: All the smart kids are selling their old gadgets. Here is how to get the highest price for those electronic goodies sitting neglected in drawers.
abstract: More than 278 million mobile devices lie idle or deactivated in the United States, and nearly half are smartphones; guide highlights how to resell them for the highest price.

headline.main: A Second Chance for Idle Electronics
headline.print_headline: A Second Chance for Idle Electronics

snippet: Apps like BuddyTV Guide, Peel and TV Guide let viewers find shows they want to watch more efficiently than by channel surfing.
abstract: Bob Tedeschi App Smart column notes apps like BuddyTV Guide, Peel and TV Guide let viewers find shows they want to watch more efficiently than by channel surfing.

headline.main: Seeing What’s on TV Without Touching the Remote
headline.print_headline: Seeing What’s on TV Without Touching the Remote

snippet: As sales of tailored clothing increase, demand grows for a less structured suit that is actually fun to wear.
abstract: Many fashion designers, responding to a growing demand for men's tailored clothing, are introducing revamped, dressed-up and stripped-down summer suits that can be mixed and matched and actually fun to wear.

headline.main: For Men, a New Look for the Summer Suit

snippet: Finding it hard to keep up with radical shifts to new modes of computing, the technology company reported sharply lower net income and confirmed a plan to pare its work force.
abstract: Hewlett-Packard is finding it hard to keep up with radical shifts to new modes of computing; will layoff 27,000 employees, or 7.7 percent of its global work force of 349,600; reports fiscal second-quarter profit of $1.59 billion, or 80 cents a share, down 31 percent from $2.3 billion, or $1.05, in the year-ago quarter; revenue fell 3 percent to $30.69 billion.

headline.main: As Computing Changes, Hewlett-Packard Struggles to Follow
headline.print_headline: As Computing Changes, H.P. Struggles to Follow

snippet: All sorts of private Internet communications were casually scooped up as Google Street View cars photographed the world’s streets.

headline.main: Google Privacy Inquiries Get Little Cooperation

byline.original: By DAVID STREITFELD and KEVIN J. O'BRIEN

snippet: The Federal Communications Commission is considering giving online distributors like Hulu and YouTube the same rights and responsibilities enjoyed by cable companies.
abstract: Federal Communications Commission is considering whether to apply regulations designed for cable television providers to online distributors like Hulu and YouTube; shift would allow online companies to distribute a greater number of popular TV shows to computers and smartphones.

headline.main: If Video Sites Could Act Like Cable Companies
headline.print_headline: If Video Sites Could Act Like Cable Companies

snippet: Though New York’s starred chefs could dine anywhere, many choose straightforward fare when they kick back.
abstract: New York's starred chefs could dine anywhere, and certainly proprietors of New York’s most distinguished restaurants would personally cook anything for them, but many culinary luminaries choose straightforward fare when they relax; favoring the casual and even the simple, they frequently return to the same couple of places and order the same thing, again and again.

headline.main: Follow a Hungry Chef and See Where It Takes You
headline.print_headline: Follow a Hungry Chef and See Where It Takes You
